title: Why is it nearly impossible to replicate Tiger Woods’ legacy
text:
Within the world of golf, greatness has been debated for years. Statistics can help aid arguments – like looking at ranks and wins. While some stats are impressive, others prove to be untouchable.
When asking the burning question of who is the greatest of all time and taking a look at the metrics of the game, it is apparent one player is in his own league: Tiger Woods.
Numbers can display clear evidence of dominating performances that can help lay the argument to rest. Players such as Rory McIlroy have accumulated a large number of weeks as No. 1. But some players had a hard time maintaining being at the top like Adam Scott.
To conceptualize how ahead Tiger is compared to other previously or currently ranked No. 1 players on a table, Wikipedia pulled data from the Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) of golfers and their weeks at the top. Another table from Wikipedia also looked at each of the four majors’ archived stats of previous winners.
The table shown is combining both of those together and is able to show how ahead Tiger was in his victory and time of reign. The players included are players that were No. 1 after Tiger’s first week of of brushing the top spot.
Tiger’s reign was not only explosive, but it was consistent and sustained. His unrelenting performances prove how far ahead he is, giving data-driven evidence that his accomplishments will be hard to bypass.
If reading the numbers didn’t fully capture how ahead Tiger is, then a visual most likely can. Transforming the table into a patchwork chart will clearly show the scale of dominance.
“But younger players like Scottie Scheffler haven’t been playing golf as long as Tiger Woods.”
Scottie Scheffler should undeniably be credited to his success and greatness as he is at the peak of his ongoing career right now. He’s bringing the level of golf that people want to see.
While Scheffler is displaying a level of greatness that Tiger once had, the standard set by Tiger is not only about reaching the top — but also how long you can sustain that greatness.
